dialogues.label: Romeo
dialogues.text:
Lady, by yonder blessed moon I vow, 
 That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops--

dialogues.label: Juliet
dialogues.text:
O, swear not by the moon, the inconstant moon, 
 That monthly changes in her circled orb, 
 Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.

dialogues.label: Juliet
dialogues.text:
Do not swear at all. 
 Or if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, 
 Which is the god of my idolatry, 
 And I'll believe thee.

dialogues.label: Juliet
dialogues.text:
Well, do not swear: although I joy in thee, 
 I have no joy of this contract tonight. 
 It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden;
 Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be 
 Ere one can say 'It lightens.' Sweet, good night! 
 This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath,
 May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Here are some cool responses from other users

default.transcript: Reading definitely takes a kind of an effort that other media don't. Video puts images directly into our brains. Easy. Reading takes more effort, cause our brains need to sound out the words and convert them into images and meanings. We call that ZINCING - taking words off the page and turning them into pictures and meanings in your head. Obviously, we all love to chill and just do easy stuff, but funny thing is, once you get comfortable with Zincing and other skills, your brain loves the effort of reading.

visualize.transcript: Your first reading move should always be to find words you can easily picture. Even in the most difficult text, a word or phrase you can picture is like a hand-hold when you're climbing a rock wall. Picture whatever you can, and then use those images to start figuring out what the whole text means.

key-images.transcript: If a writer says, "She had nice brown eyes," you just picture them, but, if she says, "She had brown eyes that sparkled like sunlight on glistening sea stones," you're getting a lot more to work with. You can imagine the brown eyes. You also picture sunlight on shiny stones in the sea. When you find a strong image like that, you wanna let yourself really see it. Then, when it's really happening in your imagination, you wanna notice all the other feelings and thoughts around that image. That's how you use a key image.

imagine.transcript: If a writer says, "She had brown eyes," you can easily visualize that. But when a writer says something less visual, like, "She hoped for good opportunities in her new home," you also need to picture something. What might these "opportunities" be? Think of something that makes sense and keep reading to find out more.

default.transcript: If you're driving a car, the paint on the road, the signs, the lights, signals from other cars - all this stuff tells you how to navigate. When you're reading, picking up the navigation clues let's you understand what the writer meant.

road-signs.transcript: Two types of road signs in a text - TRANSITION WORDS, like however, also, because, and - and punctuation - colons, semi-colons, commas, dashes and even periods. Mostly, the punctuation let's you know to expect an explanation or more details.

pronouns.transcript: Pronouns are words that act as place holders for other words - she, he, they, it, that, this. When you see a pronoun, make sure you connect it with the word or phrase it's replacing. "This led to blah, blah, blah..." What's "this"? You'll usually find pronouns replacing words or phrases that have just been mentioned or are about to be mentioned.

explainers.transcript: When a writer says something that's not completely clear, you should expect them to explain. Sometimes they give you punctuation, like a colon or dash or comma that announces, "here's the explanation!" Sometimes they just go on and explain.

default.transcript: Tone refers to the feelings behind the words. Is the author excited, or critical or angry or unsure? Look for words and phrases with a lot of flavor or contrasts between words to convey the writer's feelings.
